intro: Packera dimorphophylla, commonly known as the two-leaf paintbrush, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble small daisies. The plant features basal leaves that are broadly ovate and hairy, while the upper leaves are narrower and more elongated. It produces showy yellow flowers that bloom in the summer months, attracting various pollinators. Packera dimorphophylla thrives in moist, rocky habitats and is often found in alpine and subalpine environments.
